questions.prompt: What keyword is used to define a structure in C?
questions.explanation: The struct keyword is used to define structures in C.

questions.prompt: How do you access a member of a structure through a pointer to that structure?
questions.explanation: The arrow operator (->) is used to access structure members through a pointer.

questions.prompt: A structure can contain members of different data types.
questions.explanation: Structures can group variables of different types, unlike arrays which must contain elements of the same type.

questions.prompt: What does typedef do when used with structures?
options: Defines an alias for the structure type
questions.explanation: typedef creates an alias, so you can use the alias name instead of "struct StructName" everywhere.
p.x is 3 and p.y is 4, so p.x + p.y equals 7.

questions.prompt: Why might sizeof(struct) be larger than the sum of its members?
questions.explanation: Compilers add padding bytes between members to ensure proper memory alignment for efficiency.

questions.prompt: The order of members in a structure can affect its total size.
questions.explanation: Different member ordering can result in different amounts of padding and thus different total sizes.

questions.prompt: What is the purpose of the offsetof macro?
options: Get member offset from structure start
questions.explanation: offsetof(struct_type, member) returns the byte offset of a member within the structure.
The packed attribute tells GCC to use minimal storage without padding, at potential cost to access speed.

questions.prompt: A structure containing only chars never has padding.
questions.explanation: While chars don't need alignment, the structure itself may need end padding for array alignment.

options: A structure containing a pointer to its own type
A structure with a name member
questions.explanation: A self-referential structure contains a pointer to another instance of the same structure type (e.g., linked list nodes).

questions.prompt: What is the difference between a struct and a union?
options: Struct members share memory, union members don't
Union members share memory, struct members don't
Unions can only have two members
questions.explanation: In a union, all members share the same memory location. Only one member can be used at a time.
Since union members share memory, d.c reads the first byte of d.i, which is 65 (ASCII for 'A').

questions.prompt: What are bit fields in structures used for?
options: Packing multiple values into fewer bytes
questions.explanation: Bit fields allow specifying exact bit widths for members, useful for flags or protocol fields.

questions.prompt: Structures can be passed to functions by value in C.
questions.explanation: Structures can be passed by value (copied) or by pointer. Passing by value copies the entire structure.
